Hello everyone and welcome to our annual
Epic Games year in review. It's hard to
believe how much has happened this year
across Epic. From Unreal Engine, Unreal
Editor for Fortnite, Fab, Metahuman, the
Epic Game Store, and every part of our
ecosystem. Today, we'll be taking a look
back at some of our biggest moments,
celebrating the creativity of our
community, and sharing a few glimpses of
what's coming next. Whether you're
tuning in from our global developer
community, our fellow friends here at
Epic, or watching as a partner, player,
or developer, we're so glad you're here.
This show is all about you, the people
who design, build, and dream with us
every single day.
[Music]
It's getting a proper uniform here.
This evening, we'll be covering several
topics like Unreal Engine, the
technology powering worlds of every
kind, Unreal Editor for Fortnite, and
the developer ecosystem that's reshaping
how games are made and shared. Fab, our
unified marketplace and platform for
digital assets, and finally, our
community, the heart of Epic and the
driving force behind everything that we
build. And of course, I am not here
alone. Let's go ahead and welcome our
incredible guests for this evening.
We've uh got Tim, Wyth, Andre, and
Shard.
Hi everyone, and thank you so much for
joining us today. We've got a lot to
cover from groundbreaking tech and
developer milestones to the amazing
stories that shape 2025. So, grab a warm
drink, settle in, and let's get started
with our first topic, Unreal Engine.
Unreal Engine is the backbone of so much
creativity across games, film, and
beyond. It's been a big year for the
team, and Unreal Engine 5.7 has
officially launched, marking another
major step forward for performance,
scale, and fidelity. Each update in the
5 series has brought new power to
developers, and 5.7 is no exception.
Let's start with the big picture. Unreal
Engine 5.7 builds on everything we
learned from 5.6, fix, including that
massive 5.6.1 hot fix with more than 270
fixes and takes it even further. We
focused on performance enhancements,
smoother workflows, and empowering
developers to build worlds of any scale.
Uh Tim, I'd actually love to hear from
your perspective. What do you think
defines Unreal Engine at this point? And
what should developers take away from
these latest releases?
Yeah. Well, Unreal Engine's bringing
together the capabilities that enable
every form of high-end 3D entertainment
to uh to build and to prosper. Um, you
know, used by games of all scales, indie
games all the way up to AAA games. Uh,
so amazing stuff uh built by CD Project
RAD uh at GDC. Um, uh, as well as other
industries like film and television. You
know, they're doing some amazing things
nowadays. Uh, and uh, uh, it's just
really exciting to see all this coming
together. Um, and one of the most
exciting things is that people are
moving content back and forth. You know,
when we we used to do Fortnite
crossovers with media, we'd take, you
know, shots of their uh, assets and
rebuild them in our our custom tools.
But nowadays, you know, more and more
we're able to just import the assets,
take a car from a car maker, they built
their model in Unreal, um, we stick the
model in Fortnite and the tools are
getting more and more powerful there.
And it's really exciting. And also, you
know, we're we're at the very early
stages of uh building from Unreal Engine
5 to Unreal Engine 6. And we've talked a
bit about that to the world uh how it
represents the coming together of um uh
you know, the best of what we've built
uh you know, for Fortnite and the best
of what we have in Unreal Engine 5 and
you know brings it all into a no
compromises solution for everybody. So
it's a it's a year of with a lot of
building um and a lot of uh
forward-looking investment um you know
some of which is coming to fruition
awesomely this year and you know some of
which uh you will take uh you know is is
building the foundations for subsequent
years.
>> Yeah absolutely and uh Wyth anything
that you might have to add to that as
well?
>> No I mean the overview there is is
perfect. I think for me one thing that I
really like is the the point in the like
product life cycle we're at right now
because there's this early dreaming that
was the anchor for Unreal Engine 5 like
how can we revolutionize certain
workflows for people make it easier
democratize things that used to be hard
and you dream and so you build this this
framework for technology that is like
the anchor of that dream but now Unreal
57 we're seven releases in and things
are stabilizing a lot and so developers
I think there's a sense that that um
what was the fantasy and what is
promised is actually real for them and
that the predictability of being able to
uh build pipelines underneath this
stuff, ship amazing visuals that also
have incredible workflows to them. Like
I just think it's a really mature place
for Unreal right now and you can see
that by the things that are being
produced by the community. They're
producing incredibly mature and amazing
things. So it's a cool point in the life
cycle, I think.
>> Yeah, completely agree. Um and one of
the biggest points of acceleration this
year has been in open world technology.
Unreal Engine 5.7 continues to refine
the world partition system and streaming
pipeline, allowing large-scale
environments to run seamlessly on modern
hardware. That means bigger, denser
worlds that stay performant. We've also
continued advancing the procedural
content generation framework, making it
easier to fill massive spaces
intelligently and with tools that handle
terrain, foliage, and structure
generation dynamically. Nanite foliage
and the new procedural vegetation editor
let artists fill massive environments
with incredible detail while keeping
performance steady. And of course, one
of the most exciting showcases of these
capabilities came through the Witcher 4
tech demo, which was a great example of
how Unreal Engine's open world and
rendering systems are being used to push
storytelling and scale to new levels.
Wyth, how can you see these openw world
improvements and collaborations shaping
the types of experiences developers can
make moving forward?
>> Well, open world projects and games are
amazing and you see a whole host of them
out in the world and so we need to be
best-in-class to support that. But the
reality is is it's a Trojan horse. I
mean, open world development is
challenging. there's huge, you know,
vastness and needs for streaming, needs
for asset counts and fidelity. It all
has to scale out to really kind of crazy
places. And if you can express mastery
in that really challenging space, then
it inherently propagates to pretty much
all the other types of projects that
Unreal is good at and can be better at.
And so I actually love a a focus on open
world because it's basically just a
pressure cooker. It's a pressure cooker
for all the things that need to be, you
know, hey, I want 10 characters. No, you
want 300. And okay, well, how do we pull
that off? Turns out you got to rewrite a
whole bunch of stuff and have an
entirely new animation framework
underneath it all in order to support
that kind of thing. And that's true
everywhere you look. You know, foliage
and animation and just overall
rendering, streaming performance. Like
anywhere you look, the pressure cooker
of open world development benefits the
entire ecosystem. So, I think that's
what excites me the most about it is
it's actually great for everybody.
>> Yeah, I totally agree. Um, and let's
also kind of in that vein talk about
rendering and fidelity, right? The
pieces that make these worlds feel
really truly alive. Uh, well, one of the
pieces, Unreal Engine 5.7 brings big
updates to Nanite and Lumen and
introduces new GPUdriven systems like
Megalytes. Lumen continues to evolve,
improving real-time lighting quality and
hardware coverage across more devices.
And with Megalytes now in beta, creators
have access to even more sophisticated
dynamic lighting control for large
scenes. So, Wyth, how do you hope to see
developers using these lighting and
rendering tools to push their projects
even further?
>> Okay. I like things which are things but
also other things, which is a very Hank
Green way to say that, I know. So, I'll
clarify, but but uh fidelity, yes. And
we're we're best-in-class there. You can
make incredible pixels in Unreal Engine.
We have since since day one, that's been
a temple and we're never going to
abandon it, right? However, what are
those things? What are these features?
What is megalites? And along with the
fidelity that comes with, yeah, use as
many shadow casting lights as you want.
Inherently, it's an optimization is
really what megalytes is when you really
get down to the base of it. And it's an
optimization in a couple of ways. One is
performance. If you can scale kind of
infinitely to however many lights within
reason that you want to use in your
scene, that's from a performance and
rendering perspective super valuable.
However, it's a workflow optimization
benefit for people too because now do I
have to really care that that one
flickering candle has a shadow and I
have to optimize and uncclick the button
so that my frame rate goes up? No. And
so I think actually the I love these
things because they allow the artist to
be playful and expressive and creative,
but they also have a workflow benefit
and a performance benefit. So it's like
this triple benefit. And those are the
features that I like the most that we're
adding are the ones that benefit all of
those things because it makes projects
look better. It makes them cheaper to
make. It makes them faster to make. You
can be more playful as an expressive as
an artist. Like these are all awesome
things.
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah. you know this uh this is the
program that we started in 2020 when we
showed Nanite and Lumen to the world um
uh you know as features that had amazing
capabilities uh in the scenes that we
built them and and you know the the last
five years have been about scaling it up
to work in ever larger scenes you know
to be able to support completely open
world environments um and also to
improve the productivity of the tools uh
you nite geometry is expensive if you
use it you have to have you know massive
LOD effort um the more you can automate
these things, the easier it becomes to
build large scale games. Um, the easier
it becomes, the more uh you the more
quality work every developer can do and
the bigger bigger a game a development
team can do can carry out without being
larger, spending more money and so on,
>> right? Yeah, absolutely. Thank you both.
Wonderful points. Uh, and animation and
rigging also took a huge leap this year.
We're reducing back and forth between
external DCC tools by bringing those
workflows into the engine. Control rig
now includes physics-based rigging.
There are big upgrades to animation
editing and blending. And we've improved
performance for complex scenes. In
addition, another big change is that
Metahuman Creator is now fully
integrated inside Unreal Engine. That
means developers can build and customize
digital humans directly in engine with
expanded body options, automatic outfit
fitting, and even real-time facial
capture from a webcam or smartphone.
We've also opened up metahumans beyond
Unreal Engine itself. They're now usable
across other platforms like Unity or
Blender. And that kind of portability
encourages collaboration and creativity
across the industry. Uh Tim and Wyth,
I'd love both of your thoughts on this.
How does this shift putting these
advanced character tools right inside
the engine fit into the bigger vision
for where Unreal Engine is heading?
>> Yeah. Well, a huge thing is that uh
nowadays sodom is a is a developer
working on just one single thing. You're
often working on all the different parts
of a scene together. And the more you
can just pop from one tool to another um
you know tweaking the skeleton of a mesh
in one place, tweaking the lights in
another place um and do this highly
integrated development, the more
efficient it is. And um if you have to
exit out of Unreal Engine, go into you
know, Blender or 3D Studio Max or Maya
uh to do a little bit of geometry
editing and then export the thing, bring
it back into Unreal, it's just you're
spending a lot of your day clicking
around um transporting things around
between programs.
>> The other thing is just what you see is
what you get is really important. Being
able to see everything exactly as it
will appear in game with all my point.
>> Oh, okay. Let me get it back to you.
>> No, no, no, not at all. I I just I
couldn't agree with you more that what
you see what you get your editing in
situ in place is so huge and any
opportunity we should have to bring it
in there so you can stay in the flow as
a creator is massive and and the people
around here are sick of hearing me say
it but to me the thing that that I care
the most about is friction. Anywhere we
can reduce friction, you you see this
like exponential boon for people. And
this is what one of those critical areas
like our all our internal teams now are
basically animating rigging now in 57
making blend shapes which is a huge huge
addition all in editor in place in
context of like the cinematic or the
gameplay moment or whatever that they're
doing. the the speed that that you gain
and the the final the faster time to
quality I guess would be a way to look
at it um is really desirable. So yeah.
>> Yeah, absolutely. Um finally as well in
addition to that, it's just been an
incredible year to see how Unreal Engine
5 has been embraced this year from major
studios like CD Project Red with The
Witcher 4 to countless indie developers
like Sandfall Interactive with their
smash hit Clare Obscure Expedition 33.
It's not just games either, like you

too. Like we saw with the

Yuki's Revenge, a lost Kill Bill scene
directed by Quentyn Tarantino in Unreal
Engine and brought to life in Fortnite.
That's a great example of how filmmakers
are using real-time tools in new ways.
Adoption of the engine is growing across
every medium, and these are just a
handful of projects from this past year
alone. So Tim, looking ahead, what
excites you most about the future of
Unreal Engine?
>> Well, it's really exciting time. You
know, if you look at the development
work we've done on, you know, Fortnite
with the UFN tools and our scripting
language, um, we've been building a lot
of foundational work on which uh, the
future engine is going to be built. Um,
and uh, it's been a lot of work really
to get to the starting line of what's
next. uh which is building out and
finishing up the you know large scale
game uh game systems and APIs that going
to be exposed to Fortnite creators uh
throughout next year. Um and you know
then coming to UE6 is a unified uh
development approach to building next
generation games inside of uh you know
Fortnite and these metaverse like
ecosystems and also building standalone
games and having the ability for anybody
who builds any game to deploy it
anywhere uh into other games or as
standalone apps to app stores or console
stores or PC stores. Um it's really
exciting to see this and it's also
exciting to see that um you know the
trends underway where uh we're going to
be able to enable you know ever more
productivity improvements as you know
the computer and you know supported by
AI technologies of all kinds can give
you uh you know better iteration times
better uh capability of synthesizing
objects you know the more you can say
you know you tweak all the lights to be
you know brighter um as opposed to going
and selecting each light individually
and making it brighter you know It's
saving time and saving time means uh
being able to build better games faster.
>> Yeah, absolutely. And uh Wyth, what
about you? Anything that you're excited
about looking in the future?
>> Well, it's it's it's absolutely
the thing that's the best is when you
something comes out of nowhere that you
didn't expect. And I think we're seeing
that particularly this year there have
been releases and there's no need to to
bubble them up from the ether and put
anybody on blast or anything but like um
a team that that came out of nowhere
that you didn't really see what they
were up to. You didn't have it it wasn't
on your radar and they emerged with
something that feels unbelievably
polished. And I I feel like that's such
an amazing reflection of how far we've
come with UEE that would allow something
like these smaller projects, smaller
teams to emerge from the ether as if it
was done by hundreds and hundreds of
people in years and years of effort.
That's the thing that I think is most
exciting when I look at kind of the
future of UEE projects are the ones that
we didn't expect because we're working
on a whole bunch of stuff internally
that we're excited about and that you
know we know it's coming. But the
creators, the people are getting our
hands on our tools and technology.
Watching them emerge kind of from
nowhere with something amazing is is
super inspiring. So that's what I'm
excited about for the next year. There's
going to be more of those that we didn't
see coming.
>> Yeah, totally agree. And I they always
surprise us, too, right? Every time.
With that in mind, 5.7.1 is now
available. So be sure to update and keep
sharing your awesome work with each
other and with us, too. We love seeing
what you're up to. Every project you
create pushes and inspires us to keep
building even better tools for you. Now,
with that in mind, let's go ahead and
move into the developer ecosystem. The
world of Unreal Editor for Fortnite and
the broader Fortnite development
community. This year has been a defining
one for UFN. The tool has matured into a
major part of the Fortnite platform,
bridging the gap between traditional
game development and the Fortnite
developer community. It has become
central to how we think about the
developer economy where developers,
teams, partners, and technology all come
together to build, publish, and grow
their own experiences within Fortnite.
From your vantage point, Tim, how would
you describe the evolution of UFN this
past year?
>> Well, uh, we've built and released a lot
of systems. Um, a lot of them are, uh,
not the fullyfledged thing though, but
the starting point to build on in the
future. You know, scene graph is a big
thing. um exposing uh the beginnings of
every object that lives in your game
world um being completely accessible to
verse code, customizable um
automatically networkable and everything
else um is a huge part of our future
plans um for you know the UFN project
and also for Unreal Engine 6. Um and so
it's uh I wish we'd been able to release
more this year but an awful lot of it
was putting a lot of effort into uh
getting the foundations set up right um
so that we can build on them. Um and uh
so I think it's what we set up this year
is going to unleash a huge amount of pro
progress throughout the course of next
year as you know we go from little bits
and pieces of what's in the 3D world
being exposed to the scene graph to uh
everything being there um and uh
becoming increasingly accessible both
through uh the scripting language and
through the visual tools and the editor.
>> Yeah, absolutely. I totally agree. It
felt like a very foundational year. I'm
excited to see where things continue to
grow and expand from here. And uh Andre,
you work very closely with developers
who are building every day inside UFN.
So what kind of growth have you seen in
the community both in the quality of
work being produced and in how people
are collaborating or adopting the tools?
>> Yeah, it's been um it's been awesome to
watch. I think the the thing I'll
highlight is the new genres that I've
seen um explored in the ecosystem. Um
and nothing we planned for just uh
developers shocked us with what they
built. Um, you know, sometimes we would
build one system and I'll use the
example of, uh, we introduced a
carriable spawner, um, which was awesome
and we were excited for it, but we
didn't prepare that a whole new genre of
brain rock games would come from that
one spawner. Um, so it's really just
cool to see um, so many new genres like
new shots on goal, like developers being
really bold um, and trying new genres.
Um then I also saw like a a big push on
new publishing strategies and uh
creators hosting more and more events um
with their players and really building
communities around their events which
was great. Um, you know, last weekend we
had eight events in our ecosystem um
that developers held and one of them um
CCU um players um which was really
really cool to see and um it wasn't just
a brain rot genre. We had pet genre. We
had murder mystery. It's just really
cool to see um what creators are doing
with events going forward.
>> Yeah, absolutely. And how it's just
expanding the ecosystem at large and
what people feel emboldened to make.
It's all really cool stuff for sure. Uh
in a similar vein, you've also been
working with IP holders since the very
start of integrating them into UFN and
the developer ecosystem with some crazy
cool collaborations like with Squid
Games, K-pop Demon Hunters, and more.
What has that journey been like and how
do you see it continuing to grow?
>> Crazy cool is a great description. Um
the uh it's been an awesome journey and
I think we're really lucky to have some
amazing partners that we work with. um
you mentioned several and you know we
also had Lego and TMNT the year before
um of this and it's been really great
like you know historically when it came
to IP licensing is a developer wanted to
build something and they would license
it for a single product and it was a
complicated process and lots of
negotiations and um working on our IP
licensing program and having IP holders
um coming with us on this journey you
know really starting a movement where
there's a one-click agreement where
thousands of developers can like boom
start building a walking dead island um
has been an awesome journey and what's
really h really happened now is like the
our our ecosystem has three players in
it you know there's developers there's
Epic and there's IP holders and we're
all driving up the ecosystem um which
has been fantastic and part of the trend
too that we're seeing is not just IP
holders signing up to the program giving
their IP to creators and establishing
brand rules but al also participating as
creators so Lego has shipped a ton of
experiences. Um Disney has started
shipping experiences. Last um this week
they shipped a Percy Jackson experience
which has been phenomenal. Um so it's
been really cool to see a happy holders
and brands um not just licensing their
technology through our program but also
participating as developers themselves.
And that's been awesome to watch.
>> Yeah, absolutely. And across the 37
series and beyond, UEFn has introduced
major updates. We've seen big
improvements to verse scripting, a

engagement payout formula, and the

portal. On the gameplay side, there have

chat and verse leaderboards. So, Andre,
with so many changes, because there's
even more than what I just listed there,
what new creative opportunities are

building inside Fortnite today?
>> There's like a there's a steel thread
that runs through that where we want to
give developers as much a agency to run
their business. And you know, you
mentioned a data API which has been

has been big hit. There's some sleeper

scheduled publishing has been huge for

that's at the core of what we always

to run their business and manage their
players and build their communities. And
you know, we recently unlocked um tool
access for um in-game items um which
next year will unlock our publishing
hold. And I'm really excited to see what

to build their community, how they run

I'm really excited for this year that
Steel Thread was a lot about giving
agency to creators. Um, next year, I
think with the upgrades we have to our
economy, it's going to be huge to see
what creators build.

think even similar to what we were

just what is capable moving forward from

>> It's been really cool, too, like, you

>> Yeah, absolutely. And uh let's also take
a closer look at the technical side,
right? The scene graph beta, thin client
updates, and the epic developer
assistant and fab integration are all
designed to make development more
seamless. Scene graph gives developers
more control and access through verse,
while the fab panel allows teams to

the editor without breaking their
workflow. Coming in early 2026,
developers will be able to make custom
interactive UI widgets, opt in to enable

islands, and can control higher level

create leaderboards for their islands
using verse codes. So Tim, how do these
upcoming updates reflect Epic's
long-term vision for UEFn as both a
creative and commercial platform?
>> Well, we need to empower all developers
to build everything they want. um
including building games uh you know
over time they're as you know big and
complex is as impressive as uh any AAA

this is this is how the future of the

real serious business opportunity and
the ability to drive their own business
um and uh and to grow it. Um and so you

this year have been in support of that.
Um you know one of the things was was
sponsor um and you know this was an

know initially somebody suggested I was

is an important way to um uh for

placement. And if you're a participant

then you get benefit from the, you know,
money that goes into the pot. Um, and
that's kind of the story of a lot of the

the new creator, uh, communities

Um, and you know, if we if we back up,
like this is the foundation of business.
It's it's companies serving customers um
by delivering the best products in

in the creative industry like this uh
this is a this is our job and it's a
huge opportunity.

Um, but yeah, giving them that
